text: What is I am in French, I am?
Je suis.
In this S group, we have we are.
What is we are?
Nous sommes.
They are.
Ils sont.
They are an entirely female group.
Elles sont.
Now let's go over to the E group.
He is.
Il est.
She is.
Elle est.
One is.
On est.
Finally, formal you are.
Vous êtes.
How would you say I am busy?
Je suis occupée.
How would you say I have gone?
Je suis allée.
Again, verbs involving coming or going in any sense require to be in the past.
That is require am or is or are when used in the past.
So again, I have gone.
Je suis allée.
I went.
I went.
I went.
Je suis allée.
I did go.
Je suis allée.
I went there.
J'y suis allée.
J'y suis allée.
Again, keep in mind the rule we've established.
Normally, the pronouns such as le and me and y, they go wherever the most obvious place is for them really.
For instance, what was to eat?
Manger.
To eat it.
Le manger.
To understand.
Comprendre.
To understand it.
Le comprendre.
To go.
Aller.
To go there.
Y aller.
However, when there is a have in the sentence, have always steals the pronouns and puts them directly in front of itself.
So, let's look at another sentence.
How would you say you have gone?
Literally, you are gone.
How would you say that?
Again, verbs involving coming and going always used to be in the past.
That's either is or am or are depending on who it is you're talking about.
So, how would you say you have gone there?
Notice that again, have has stolen the pronoun or the proxy noun.
Again, you may be wondering, where is the have?
Well, it's true.
In the French sentence, there actually is no have.
It's literally, you are gone there.
However, have always steals the pronoun.
And when to be is taking the place of have, it also steals the pronoun.
So, obviously, in the English sentence, we have, you have gone.
You have gone there.
So, have steals the pronoun.
Even when in these few occasions where to be is standing in for have, it will steal the pronoun.
Let's try a couple more examples.
How would you say you have eaten?
You have eaten it.
You see how have has stolen the pronoun and put it directly in front of itself.
Now, if we want to say you have gone, obviously, we can't actually use the real have because that's not permitted in French.
Again, French is like old English.
If you look in books, two, three, four hundred years ago, you find quite different form of English.
You find something like, your friend is come to see you.
Not your friend has come to see you, but your friend is come to see you.
Also, he is gone yesterday rather than he has gone yesterday.
This difference used to exist in English too, but it's gone from modern English.
It remains in French, however.
So, again, verbs involving going or coming in any sense.
So, to go, to arrive, to come, to leave, to go out, to go down, to go up, to go out of the world, meaning to die, to come into the world, meaning to be born.
All of these verbs required to be in the past.
They're quite a small group, however, but it's good to get to grips with the idea.
So, one more time.
What is we are?
Nous sommes.
And how would you say we have gone?
Nous sommes allés.

Now, using e for there and remembering that have always steals the pronouns or if something is standing in for have, so if are is standing in for have as it is here, it will also steal the pronouns on have's behalf more or less.
So, how would you say we have gone there?
Nous y sommes allés.
We went there.
We went there yesterday.
Nous y sommes allés hier.
We went there yesterday morning.
Nous y sommes allés hier matin.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
Again, let's look at that in detail.
Going back to what is we are.
We went there.
We went there.
We went there yesterday morning.
We went there yesterday morning.
How do you say we are there using e?
Nous y sommes.
We are not there.
We are not there.
Nous n'y sommes pas.
We didn't go there.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
We didn't go there yesterday morning.
Why didn't we go there yesterday morning?
Why didn't we go there yesterday morning?
That was an extremely tricky sentence, requiring the juggling of very many aspects of French grammar.
If you find yourself able to do it at this point, then it means you've already crossed some of the most difficult hurdles in French.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
You've got to be on the same way.
